results.title: Swords and ploughshares
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
EPISODE 2 OF OUT OF THE FIERY FURNACE - Iron became a universal replacement for bronce; techniques evolved to “steel”, quench and temper it. The Bronze Age collapsed when a new metal “iron” emerged. The Chinese who were the first to cast it, developed huge blast furnaces. The Hittites, of Turkey, were the first to make iron of good quality, and the iron age spread from Damascus throughout Europe. Shows the importance of mining to the ancient civilizations of Grece and Rome. Presented by Michael Charlton.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films

results.title: From stone to bronze
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
Episode 1 in the fascinating series called “Out of the fiery furnace.” Opening in the Stone Age this episode explores how mankind came to recognize metals, showing their accidental production in an Indian pottery kiln, and an experiment in smelting copper in the Sinai using Egyptian techniques of about 1500 BC.

results.title: The Chain of life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Vanishing Wilderness”.
Man is destroying his environment when he uses chemical instead of biological pesticide controls. Man is the end link in the chain of life and is limiting his own survival when he destroys other links in that chain.
results.description:

results.title: Slow death of desert water
results.creator_credit: Shelly Grossman and National Educational Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Vanishing Wilderness”.
Shows what is happening to Pyramid Lake, in Nevada, and its wild life because dams divert its source of water and sonic booms frighten its wild life. Based on the book “Our vanishing wilderness” by Mary Louise and Shelly Grossman and John Hamlet, 1969.

results.title: Santa Barbara: everybody's mistake
results.creator_credit: Shelly Grossman and National Educational Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Vanishing Wilderness”.
Examines the controversies behind the 2 million gallon oil leak in the Santa Barbara Channel, off the coast of California in 1969. Shows how smog created by oil is killing pine trees high above sea level. The film asks why a society places such a high value on oil that it willingly endangers its own life. Based on the book “Our Vanishing Wilderness” by Mary Louise and Shelly Grossman and John Hamlet.

results.title: Where is my story?

results.title: What's the name of that place you come from nan?
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Rita Hinekauia Morrison
results.brief_description: Rita comes from a mixed cultural background but her strongest connection is with the Maori side of her family. She shares her memories and family history in this digital story so that her Maori heritage can be preserved through future generations.

results.title: Vicki's story
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Vicki Atkinson
results.brief_description: Vicki reminisces about her family and childhood and how she looked up to her parents as role models hoping that what she has learned from them can be passed on to her own two daughters. This is her message.
results.description: Vicki reminisces about her family and childhood and how she looked up to her parents as role models hoping that what she has learned from them can be passed on to her own two daughters. This is her message.
